Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multicellular Communication in Gradient Sensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Epidermal growth factor gradient sensing by epithelial cells is a crucial process in development and many disease processes such as cancer metastasis. Understanding the basic principles of this sensing would enable us to intervene in disease processes that involve directional cell motion by pharmacologically targeting the communication rather than the within-cell regulation, and it can stimulate a novel direction for therapeutics. Through a combination of novel experimental and theoretical approaches, this project will characterize advantages and limitations of multicellular gradient sensing in breast epithelial tissue in a mouse model. It will explore the fundamental physical limits on collective gradient sensing and will establish to which extent the size of multicellular ensembles aids their sensory precision. The project will also support synergistic curriculum development efforts on the interface of physics and biology at three research universities, on levels from introductory undergraduate to advanced graduate. It will provide research and broader career training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs, including minority students. The PIs will engage elementary school students in science projects and they will reach out to the general public disseminating their research findings at the Atlanta Science Festival.

Cells in multicellular organisms rarely act alone in responding to external signals, but little is known about behaviors that emerge from their multicellular, collective communication and action. In particular it is unknown if multicellular ensembles can collectively sense chemical gradients in ways that take advantage of such ensembles spanning substantial ranges of the chemo-attractant concentration. The PIs' experiments with multicellular ensembles of breast epithelial cells exposed to gradients of epidermal growth factor suggest that these cells can sense gradients collectively and that collectively cells respond to gradients that are far smaller than those sensed by individual cells. This multicellular information processing is fundamentally distinct from, and not simply reducible to, sensory processes in isolated cells. The PIs will establish theoretically and verify experimentally the fundamental physical limits on the precision of gradient sensing by multicellular ensembles. These limits containing contributions from the extrinsic ligand stochasticity and from the intrinsic noise in communicating the measurements made by distant cells in a multicellular group to individual cells within the group will be characterized. The PIs will develop computational methods to analyze precision of biological information processing in collective, nonlinear phenomena, such as epithelial tissue rearrangement, which will be applicable broadly in other biophysical contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our grant was jointly proposed and conducted with Professor Nemenman (Emory) and Professor Levchenko (Yale). The common mission was to achieve a deeper understanding of the ways in which cells communicate during organ development in mammals. We had a specific emphasis on how multicellular groups can detect and respond to spatial patterns of chemical signals. This project was organized around preliminary experiments and computational analyses from the three labs that suggested that groups of cells had much higher sensitivity to chemical gradients than do single cells. Our NSF funding enabled us to address the following related questions: (1) how do groups of cells detect signals, such as EGF, and how accurate is their sensing? (2) What are the fundamental theoretical limits on multicellular gradient sensing? (3) How close are the cells in our experimental systems to these theoretical limits? We were able to answer each of these questions (Ellison et al, PNAS, 2016), as well as conducting follow-up studies that revealed how the sensing of gradients is coupled to cell migration (Huebner et al, Development, 2016) and how chemical and mechanical signals are integrated to couple gradient sensing to cell migration to epithelial tube elongation (Neumann et al, Developmental Cell, 2018).

Summary of Results: We experimentally demonstrated that groups of cells can function as multicellular detectors and respond to gradients as small as 0.2% over 10 microns, 10 fold more sensitively than single cells. This improved sensitivity depended on both gap junctions and calcium release. We infer that the signal is transduced through activation of the MAPK pathway, as selective spatial activation of ERK was sufficient to induce new ducts to form and elongate. The experimental and theoretical analyses converged to reveal that the functional unit for sensing was approximately 3-4 cell layers deep and involved 20-50 cells. Theoretical analysis revealed that intracellular noise placed limits on the efficiency of integrating signals from cells beyond this scale.  These calculations were also consistent with our quantitative assessments of the effect of group size, location within the gradient, and both absolute and relative gradient level on response.

We next sought to understand how the detection of a graded chemical signal was converted to cell movement and ultimately to changes in organ shape. This required quantitative analysis of the spatio-temporal activation of signaling pathways while tracking cell and tissue shape dynamics. To accomplish these goals, we used biosensors inside the cell that reported on molecular decision making with fluorescent light. We then collaborated with the Brodland lab at the University of Waterloo to adapt civil engineering analysis techniques to infer force and tension at the cellular and tissue level. We then integrated our experimental observations from across a decade's worth of papers to build the first finite element model of mammary branching morphogenesis. Our computational model reflected the specific geometry, number of cell layers, and cell number characteristic of elongating mammary ducts in vivo. After several rounds of simulation, comparison with experiment, and revision of the model, we succeeded in developing a model that could explain ductal elongation using only cell behaviors and mechanical relationships that we imaged and inferred in living cells.

Broader Impacts: Funding from this grant supported the research efforts and experimental costs for three members of the Ewald Lab: Neil Neumann, Daniel Kim, and Andrew Fraser. Neil Neumann is an MD/PhD student in our Biochemistry Cell and Molecular Biology PhD Program. He learned and performed 3D culture, time-lapse DIC and confocal microscopy, quantitative molecular biosensor imaging, and computational modeling. Neil has completed his PhD and is entering his final year of medical school, with plans to become a pathologist / scientist working at the interface of normal development and cancer invasion. Daniel Kim was an undergraduate researcher in the lab and learned 3D culture, histology, time-lapse microscopy, and quantitative image analysis. He graduated from Hopkins and will enter UCSF for medical school in Fall 2018. Andrew Fraser is an MD/PhD student in our Biomedical Engineering PhD program. He is learning 3D culture, computational modeling, molecular biosensor imaging, quantitative image analysis and both pharmacologic and genetic interventions. He is now supported on NIH funds and will be collaborating with Andrew Mugler, a new faculty member in the Hopkins Physics and Biophysics Departments.
